journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part E: Journal of Process Mechanical Engineering

title-group.article-title: Precise signed digraph modelling based on causal dependence identification

article-meta.aff: State Key Laboratory for Manufacturing Systems Engineering, Xi’an Jiaotong University, China

author-notes.corresp: Zhiyong Gao, State Key Laboratory for Manufacturing Systems Engineering, Xi’an Jiaotong University, Xi’an 710049, China. Email: lincambrage@sina.com

abstract.p: The fault diagnosis approach based on signed digraph is promising, but signed digraph models built by existing methods often contain false causalities and make spurious diagnosis results. In this article, a signed digraph modelling method based on causal dependence identification is proposed. Many equations used to describe mechanism of process system can be used to analyse the cause–effect relation between state variables and build precise signed digraph models. The cause–effect relation hided in system equations is extracted through causal dependence identification of algebraic and differential equations. Signed digraph model is then constructed by merging the analysis results. The method of causal dependence identification and strongly connected components identification of process system is investigated in detail. Algorithm of causal dependence identification is summarized and results in a simple but effective signed digraph construction procedure. The validity of the proposed method was tested by the case study of signed digraph modelling for a series connected liquid storage system, and the efficiency of the algorithm was tested by another case study of a compressor unit system. The comparison result shows that the proposed method can extract precise causal dependence relation between state variables from system equations and build signed digraph model effectively with less resource consumption, which is very important for building signed digraph model of large scale process system.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Modern process industry plants are becoming larger and more complex. This makes abnormal event management and fault diagnosis of process systems become more difficult than ever. Different from the simple system with one or several sets of equipment, large scale process system like petrochemical process plants often have numerous sets of equipment which are closely contacted and interacted. Faults happened in individual equipment not only make itself working abnormally, but also affect other equipment and often cause the whole system fail to work eventually.1 In the many fault diagnosis approaches, signed digraph (SDG) based diagnosis method is perspective for large-scale process systems because the SDG model can represents the interaction and cause–effect relation between the many connected equipment without number limitation, and the SDG model can be effectively used to trace the root cause of system failure. However, the SDG models developed by existing methods often contain false causalities which often make spurious diagnosis results. Those spurious results seriously reduce the diagnosis effect and make the fault diagnosis method based on SDG, which seems not very reliable in practical applications.2 What is more, SDG models are often manually built by operators according to the flow sheets of processes. It is acceptable for small-scale process systems. However, for large-scale process systems, it is very time-intensive and unreliable.

Some mathematical methods used to build SDG model have been proposed. The earliest method based on system equations was proposed by Iri et al.3 and Umeda et al.4 In their method, the cause–effect relation is obtained by directly converting the equivalence relation between variables on two sides of the equals into causality relation. This method implies a problem that the mathematical operation of changing the position of variables in the equation will introduce false causalities. Li et al.5 proposed a method of building SDG models based on interactive equations among system variables. The method is effective when interactive equations are constructed as needed in advance, but the interaction equations construction is still rely on experience. Oyeleye and Kramer6 proposed a SDG constructing method using confluences which was used in qualitative simulation. The spurious solutions are reduced using latent constraints associated with analytically redundant model equations and nonlatent constraints based on causality. Maurya et al.7 took advantage of the method proposed by Oyeleye and Kramer6 and proposed a systematic digraph modelling method based on system equations using perfect matching. From many contributions focusing on SDG, it can be seen that high accuracy of SDG model is necessary for achieving reliable diagnosis results. However, the existing SDG modelling methods are not able to building SDG model precisely and effectively, especially for large-scale process system which containing numerous variables with complex relation,8 the existing SDG modelling method will be very time consuming.

In this article, a SDG modelling method based on causal dependence identification is proposed. Causal dependence identification based on causal ordering analysis is performed to obtain accurate cause–effect relation between state variables. Then, the cause–effect relation from the identification results on different structures of the system are merged and constructed into SDG model. The key issues of identifying causal dependence based on causal ordering analysis and distinguishing strongly connected components (SCCs) in process system, as well as constructing SDG model based on different cause–effect analysis results are investigated in detail. From the investigation, it can be seen that causal ordering analysis on system equations is an effective way to identify cause–effect relation between system variables. The further research of causal dependency identification and SCCs identification based on causal ordering analysis enhances the approach and results in improved and effective SDG modelling method. Two case studies including causal dependence identification and SDG modelling for a series connected liquid storage system and a large-scaled compressor unit system were illustrated at last. The comparison result analysis shows that the proposed method can accurately extract cause–effect relation between state variables from system equations and effectively construct precise SDG model for large-scaled process system.

sec.title: Causal dependence identification of process system
sec.p: Process system contains many physical and chemical equations that can be obtained from many ways, such as design documents. These system equations describe the mechanism of process system in mathematical form and contain precise essential information about the system. The cause–effect relation between state variables extracted from system equations will be accurate and reliable if the extraction method is proper. The method of Iri et al.3 often brings false causalities into SDG model because it directly treats algebraic equations as causal relation expressions. The cause–effect relation between system variables is hided in system equations in a complicated hierarchical form which should be identified through particular process. Simon9 has proposed the concept of ‘causal ordering’ which was used to represent the cause–effect relation and hierarchical causal dependence between variables of the system described by equations. Preliminary investigation has been done by Simon10 and Iwasaki and Simon11 on how to identify the causal orders. Iwasaki also indicated the rule of how to determine the causal dependence between variables in different orders, but the principle was not explained of why the causal dependence can be accurately deduced following the rule. Furthermore, the problem of how to identify SCCs of process system was not investigated. These two issues were studied in this section. Following the detailed investigation of causal dependence identification between variables in different orders and causal dependence identification of system with SCCs, an algorithm of causal dependence identification of process system is concluded.

sec.title: Causal ordering
sec.p:
Algebraic equations of a system not only describe the steady-state equilibrium relationship between variables, but also contain the causal dependence between variables. The mathematical foundation of this conclusion and derivation of causal ordering analysis has been described by Simon10 in detail. The procedure of causal ordering analysis proposed by Iwasaki and Simon11 was briefly quoted as below in order to facilitate our investigation.
Step 1: Given a self-contained equilibrium structure S described by algebraic equations, find out the proper subset S′ that is also self-contained and does not contain any proper self-contained subset. S′ is called a minimal self-contained subset of S.
Step 2: Let S0 be the union of all such minimal self-contained subsets of S. S0 is called the zero-order minimal complete subset of the system. Since S0 is self-contained, the values of all the variables in S0 can be obtained by solving the equations in S0.
Step 3: By substituting these variables with their solved values in the set (S − S0), a new self-contained structure is obtained, which is called the first-order derived structure. Let S1 be the set of minimal complete subsets of this derived structure. It is called the first-order minimal complete subset of the system.
Step 4: Repeat the above steps until the derived structure of the highest order contains no proper self-contained subset.
Rule 1: For each equation Ei in S, let Vi denote the set of variables appearing in Ei, and let Wi denote the subset of Vi containing the variables belonging to the minimal complete subset of the highest order. Then, the variables in Wi are said to be directly causally dependent on the elements in (Vi − Wi).
The four steps classify variables of a system into different orders and Rule 1 determines the causal dependence of variables in different orders.

This procedure was illustrated by the example of evaporator shown in Figure 1(a). The evaporator system has eight variables (Q, Ti, To, G, H, P, Tc and Tw) in equations (1) to (4). Variables Ti, Q, P and Tw are exogenous ones determined by environment. Four constant equations were added to make the system self-contained. The equations are listed below (1)H=k(Tw-Tc) (2)H=GQI-(Ti-To)Qs (3)Tc=f1(P) (4)To=Tc (5)Ti=c1 (6)Q=c2 (7)P=c3 (8)Tw=c4 Figure 1.
Evaporator and causal order structure.

After causal ordering analysis, these eight variables are classified into four order sets, which are the zero-order set (contains P, Tw, Q, Ti), the first-order set (contains Tc), the second-order set (contain To, H) and the third-order set (contains G). The causal structure shown in Figure 1(b) was constructed based on this hierarchical causal order sets and rule 1.

From the explanation of the Iwasaki and Simon,11 the causal structure shown in Figure 1(b) is consistent with the mechanism of the evaporator. Thus, it is an accurate causal dependence structure of the evaporator system. But the causal ordering analysis results needs a detailed explanation about how rule 1 construct the causal structure based on the different order sets. This issue was discussed in detail in the next section and an algorithm based on causal dependence identifying procedure was concluded further.

sec.title: Causal dependence identification
sec.p:
Since the variables are obtained from system equations, when they are put back into the equations, the causal dependence relation between variables will also be brought into the system. The equations then can be dissected following the causal dependence relation between variables. The causal structure and how the hierarchical causal dependence formed will be revealed. The evaporator system is still taken as the example to illustrate the causal dependence identification process. As shown in Figure 2, the causal dependence forming process was decomposed into seven steps (a → g). Figure 2.
Causal dependence identification process of evaporator system: (a) to (g) denotes the causal dependence identifying procedure and (h) the causal structure identified. In (a) to (g), (1)–(8) in the top row indicates the number of equations of evaporator system. Notations in the first column denote variables of the system. Dot in the grid indicates that the variable of the row appears in the equation of the column. The rectangle on the dot indicates the variable is identified to be in some causal order set. The circle on the dot indicates that the value of the variable is determined. The dashed arrows from rectangles to circles in rows represent the value transferring relation from variable in one equation (rectangle dots) to itself in the other equation (circled dot). The solid arrows in columns denote the causal dependence relation between different variables in one equation.

According to the result of causal ordering analysis, the eight variables are separated into four order sets. The variables of the higher order are determined by the variables of the lower order. The influence from lower order variables to higher order variables is not directly transferred, but through the inner path decided by equation structure. The four variables of the zero order (P, Tw, Q, Ti) are denoted by rectangles in Figure 2(a). They are exogenous variables determined by factors outside of the evaporator system. These four variables also appear in equations (1) to (3), denoted by circles. So, the four variables in equations (1) to (3) are determined because they are decided by external factors in equations (5) to (8) and cannot change arbitrarily in equations (1) to (3). This determination relation is indicated by the dashed arrows from rectangles to circles in Figure 2(b). In Figure 2(b), there are only two variables (Tc and P) in equation (3). P has been determined. So, Tc is decided by P, indicated by solid arrow in Figure 2(c). Since Tc has been decided, the value of Tc in equations (1) and (4) should also be decided, indicated by circled dots of Tc and dashed arrows as shown in Figure 2(d). Then, in the first column of equation (1), since Tw and Tc have been decided, the only left variable H should be causally dependent on Tw and Tc, which is denoted by solid arrows from Tw to H and from Tc to H in Figure 2(e). H itself is denoted by rectangle because it is causally decided by other variables in the same equation. Similarly, To is causally dependent on Tc in equation (4), denoted by rectangle on variable To and solid arrow from Tc to To in Figure 2(e). At last, we can see in Figure 2(f), only one variable G is left in equation (2). So, it is causally dependent on all other variables in the equation, as denoted in Figure 2(g). After all variables are determined, the causal dependence relation was summarized and drawn in Figure 2(h). It is identical with the result illustrated by Iwasaki.

From the causal dependence identification process, it can be seen that one variable may appear in several equations. The value of the variable will transfer by itself between different equations, step by step, first from outside factor into the zero order and then from lower order to higher order. Different variables in one equation then have causal dependence relation. The variable undetermined is dependent on variables that have been determined. This value transferring by variable and causal dependence between variable form the hierarchical causal structure of the system.

The causal order sets were also obtained along with causal dependence identification process, even it was not done on purpose. In Figure 2(a), four variables in rectangles are in the set of minimal complete subsets of zero order which was identified as exogenous variables. While in Figure 2(c), Tc was identified to be the only variable causally dependent on other variables. Therefore, it is the only variable in the set of minimal complete subsets of the first order. To and H was identified in Figure 2(e) to be causally dependent on other variables. They form the set of minimal complete subsets of the second order. G was found to be causally dependent on other variables in Figure 2(g). It forms the set of minimal complete subsets of the third order. These results are just identical to the result obtained by causal ordering analysis. So, the causal dependence identification process illustrated in Figure 2 not only identifies the causal dependence relation, but also performs causal ordering analysis. This kind of causal ordering analysis method is different from that proposed by Iwasaki was summarized into an algorithm, as shown in Figure 3. It has been tested by the example of evaporator system and several large-scale process systems. The algorithm can be effectively executed in computer when number of equations of a system becomes very large. All the works should be done manually only to make the system self-contained in advance by identifying exogenous variables. Figure 3.
Algorithm of causal dependence identification.

sec.title: Causal ordering analysis for self-contained system with SCCs
sec.p: SDG model often contains SCCs, in which several nodes that are strongly connected. Variables of nodes in SCC affect each other without definite order. So, there are no causal orders between variables of a SCC. SCCs should be identified and replaced by single nodes to facilitate SDG modelling.

In the method of Maurya et al.7 SCCs may exist if the bipartite graph of system equations and variables has more than one perfect matching. This statement is correct, but the authors did not investigate the relation between SCC and perfect matching in detail. In their method, SCCs are still manually identified in the bipartite graph following some procedure.
Pay more attention to the example introduced by Maurya et al.7 as shown in example 2.

Three perfect matchings can be found in the bipartite graph of this system, as shown in Figure 4. In all these three perfect matchings, the relation between equation (12) and variable x2 is constant. But the equations corresponding to variable x1, x3 and x4 are varying according to different perfect matchings. Therefore, x1, x3 and x4 affect one another through indeterminate way and they form one SCC. Figure 4.
Bipartite graph and perfect matchings of example 2.

It can be seen that all the SCCs in a system can be found by finding out all perfect matchings, but it is a little time intensive when building SDG model for a large-scale complex system following the method proposed by Maurya et al.7 The method needs to construct a graph between all variables in the equations first and manipulate the graph by eliminating noncausal edges. The perfect matching also needs to be found through the bipartite graph of equations and variables through another algorithm. This graph manipulation is usually performed in computer by iteration algorithm and adjacency matrix stored in database by adjacency table. For a large-scale complex system which often has thousands of variables, reading and writing records from tables of database too, frequently will consume much resource of the computer and spend much time. This can be seen from the second case study.

In fact, there is a more convenient and reliable way to find SCCs just within the equations and needs not to construct graph. From the relation between equation structure and variables, it can be proved that SCCs are those subsystems of a system which are self-contained and contain at least two variables. In example 2, structure of the system changed into Figure 5 after eliminating variables in the set of minimal complete subsets of zero order. In this structure, equations (9) to (11) contain variables x1, x3 and x4. They form determined and solvable self-contained subsystem, but no one of the three variables can be solved by a single equation in this subsystem. So, these three variables are strongly connected and form a SCC, in which causal orders among the variables are not explicit. Figure 5.
Structure of example 2 after eliminating variables of zero-order set.

It can be concluded further that all those self-contained subsystems, containing at least two variables which do not contain self-contained subsystems themselves and cannot be solved by single equation, are SCCs. The typical form of this subsystem is shown in equation group (13) (13){c11x1+c12x2+c13x3+…+c1nxn+c1=0c21x1+c22x2+c23x3+…+c2nxn+c2=0…cn1x1+cn2x2+cn3x3+…+cnnxn+cn=0

According to Cramer rule, the value of every variable can be calculated through (xi=Di/D). Determinant Di and D are determined by all the coefficients. In the equilibrium state, the values of all the variables will keep constant. Anyone of these coefficients changes (which means system environment or system structure changed) will cause all the variables change their values. Since there is no more self-contained subsystem contained in this subsystem, the causal-dependent relation cannot be in hierarchical form. The only possible structure in which any change will cause all variables to change their values will be SCC.

This kind of self-contained subsystem can be easily identified by mathematical rules of judging solvability of the equations. Hence, it is convenient to identify all SCCs in a large-scale process system. Following this conclusion, the procedure of causal dependence identification for equilibrium structure is improved. The improved algorithm of causal dependence identification for system containing SCCs or not is shown as below. There may be the situation in practice that some SCCs include weighted branches and thus cannot be simplified. The algorithm illustrated below focuses on the identification of causal dependence of variables and SCCs included in the system. The simplification of SCCs in the SDG construction procedure should be modified to adapt to different situations. When SCCs include weighted branches, the nodes should not be simply merged and reduced into one node but should be remained with their interrelation and weighted branches.

sec.title: The algorithm

list-item.p: Given a self-contained equilibrium structure S0 described by algebraic equations, transform all the nonlinear equations into linear equations according to de Kleer and Brown.12
Find out all constant equations of S0.

Find out all self-contained subsystem of S0 containing at least two equations. These subsystems form SCCs of the system. The constant equations and SCCs of S0 form the minimal complete subset S0 of the zero order of S0. This step contains two sub-steps as below.
Find out an equation with two variables in S0. Find all equations containing those variables. If the number of equations equals the number of variables, then calculate the determinant D of the coefficients matrix of the variables. If D ≠ 0, the equations form a self-contained subsystem of S0. Find out all these self-contained subsystems with two equations in S0.
Increase the number of variables of the equation, repeat step 3.1. Find out all self-contained subsystems with at least two equations in S0. These self-contained subsystems form SCCs of S0.
In the set (S0 − S0), substituting those variables which have appeared in S0 with their solved values, a new self-contained structure is obtained.

Repeat the above steps in the obtained new self-contained structure until the derived structure of the highest order contains no self-contained subsets. Then, all sets of minimal complete subsets of each order are identified.

For each equation Ei in S, let Vi denote the set of variables appearing in Ei and Wi the subset of Vi containing the variables belonging to the minimal complete subset of the highest order. Then, the variables in Wi are directly causally dependent on the variables in (Vi − Wi).

sec.p:
This algorithm needs only one table to store system equations by two fields which are equation number and variables contained in each equation. Variables contained in one equation are stored by one string and separated by special character like comma. The iteration of variables between different equations is executed in the code by character operation. For example, the variables of equation (1) in example are stored by string ‘H, Tw, Tc’. The iteration between equations can be performed in the code by string operation function such as character searching and substitution, which can be realized by C or C# (or other language) and conveniently embedded into webpage (which was taken in our project) or other program. The detailed procedure of the algorithm was illustrated in flowchart, as shown in Figure 6. Figure 6.
Flowchart of the algorithm of causal-dependent relation identification.

sec.title: SDG model construction
sec.p: Most process systems are mixed systems comprised of equilibrium structures and dynamic structures. Equilibrium structures are often described by algebraic equations. Causal dependence between variables of equilibrium structures can be obtained by causal dependence identification using the improved algorithm we proposed. Dynamic structures are often described by differential equations. Causal dependence identification of dynamic structures has been investigated by Iwasaki. The differential equations of dynamic structure can be transformed into canonical form. The equations in canonical form represent the mechanism of the dynamic structure. The variables on the right side of the equations determine the time trajectory of the derivatives in the left side. Therefore, variable xi, whose derivative appears in the ith equation, is said to be directly causally dependent on the variables appear in the equation with non-zero coefficient.

After the causal dependence of equilibrium structures and dynamic structures has been identified, the causal dependence relation of a mixed system can be obtained by combining the causal dependence of those sub-structures. SDG modelling for this kind of mixed system as well as simply equilibrium system or dynamic system can be easily achieved based on the causal dependence identification. For a self-contained mixed system M composed of equilibrium structure and dynamic structure with n variables and n equations, define D(M) to be the subset containing all the differential equations in M, define S(M) to be the subset containing all algebraic equations and constant equations added for those variables whose derivatives exist in differential equations of D(M). The SDG modelling of mixed system M based on causal dependence identification can be realized as following steps.
Step 1: Preprocess: Decompose those composed algebraic equations into structural equations following system mechanism. Transform differential equations into canonical form. Find those exogenous variables and add constant equations into S(M) for each of them. In addition, constant equations should also be added into S(M) for those variables whose derivatives appear in D(M).
Step 2: Perform causal dependence identification for D(M) according to the process of causal ordering analysis of dynamic structure.
Step 3: Perform causal dependence identification for S(M) through the algorithm of causal dependence identification of equilibrium structure.
Step 4: Identify qualitative causal-dependent effect. The sign of the ratio between coefficients of causal and effect variables indicates the qualitative causal-dependent effect. The qualitative causal-dependent effect can be divided into promotive influence for positive ratio and suppression influence for negative ratio.
Step 5: Draw nodes and directed branches to represent variables and their causal-dependent relation. Replace branches by directed real lines representing promotive causal effect relation and broken lines representing suppressive causal effect relation, or place ‘+’ signs and ‘−’ signs on the branches to represent their causal-dependent effect. This step transforms the causal-dependent relation into signed directed graph.
Step 6: Complete SDG modelling by merging the repeated variables and edges that appear both in D(M) and S(M) and combining the SDG models of D(M) and S(M) into one model. If the system contains only equilibrium structures or dynamic structures, the combination step can be omitted.

sec.title: SDG modelling construction of series connected liquid storage system
sec.p:
Equations (14) to (21) describe the mechanism of a typical series connected liquid storage system comprised of three storage tanks with pipes and valves, which is often used in process system. The structure of the storage system is shown in Figure 7. In this case study, equation (15) has been transformed intentionally from its initial form by exchanging the positions of P1 and P2 in order to testify the validation of our method. (14)P1=0.0 2V10.6+1 (15)P1=P2-ρgH1 (16)P3=ρgH2+P0 (17)F1=k2V2(P2-P3)0.5 (18)F2=k3V3(ρgH3)0.5 (19)A1dH1/dt=-F1 (20)A2dH3/dt=F1-F2 (21)A3dH4/dt=F2 Figure 7.
Series connected liquid storage system.

The system consists of 13 variables in eight equations. Variables of P0, V1, V2, V3 and H2 are exogenous ones determined by factors outside of the system. Thus, five equations should be introduced as shown in equations (22) to (26) (22)P0=c1 (23)V1=c2 (24)V2=c3 (25)V3=c4 (26)H2=c5
Three constant equations were added for H1, H3 and H4, whose derivatives appear in the differential equations. (27)H1=c6 (28)H3=c7 (29)H4=c8

Equations (14) to (18) and (22) to (29) form the subset S(M) of the system. Causal-dependent relation of S(M) was analysed according to the causal dependence identification procedure of equilibrium structure. The causal-dependent relation of S(M) obtained is shown in Figure 8. Figure 8.
Causal dependence relation of S(M) of the storage system.

Equations (19) to (21) form the subset D(M) of the system. Causal-dependent relation of D(M) was analysed according to causal ordering analysis procedure of dynamic structure. Dependence relation of variables and derivatives of D(M) was shown in Figure 9(a) and causal dependence of variables of D(M) was shown in Figure 9(b). Figure 9.
Causal dependence relation of D(M) of the storage system; (a) dependence of variables and derivatives; (b) causal dependence of variables.

The SDG model of series connected liquid storage system was at last constructed by representing causal dependence relations of S(M) and D(M) in SDG form at first, and then combining the SDG models of D(M) part and S(M) part into one integrated SDG model through merging the repeated nodes and edges of H1, H3, F1 and F2 which appear both in D(M) and S(M). SDG model developed based on causal dependence identification of the series connected liquid storage system was shown in Figure 10. Figure 10.
SDG model of the series connected liquid storage system.

sec.title: Comparison analysis
sec.p:
For comparison, SDG model of the series connected liquid storage system was also built according to the modelling method proposed by Iri et al.3 The SDG model constructed was shown in Figure 11. Figure 11.
Comparison SDG model of the series connected liquid storage system.

There are two differences between the SDG model shown in Figure 10 and that in Figure 11. The direction of the arrow between P1 and P2 in Figure 10 is inversed in Figure 11. Connection between H1 and P2 in Figure 10 was eliminated in Figure 11 and replaced by connection between H1 and P1. According to the mechanism of the series connected liquid storage system, P2 is a passive variable determined by P1 and H1. P2 is not able to serve as an initial causative variable without driven from other variables. P1 is only determined by V1 which can be concluded from equation (14). Therefore, causal dependence from P2 to P1 and that from H1 to P1 in Figure 11 are false causalities. It is obvious that causal dependence from P2 to P1 and that from H1 to P1 in Figure 11 were directly obtained from equation (15). P2 and H1 lie in the right side of equation (15). P1 lies in the left side of equation (15). According to the traditional SDG modelling method, causal dependence positions P2 → P1 and H1 → P1 were obtained directly from the equation. However, equation (15) has been transformed from its initial form by exchanging the positions of P1 and P2 intentionally in order to testify the validation of our method. The traditional method has not identified the transformation and obtained false causal dependence between system variables. The method proposed by us successfully avoided the interference of the equation transformation. The causal dependence between system variables was accurately extracted and the SDG model built based on this causal dependence is valid.

sec.title: SDG modelling construction of compressor unit system
sec.p:
Large-scale systems like petrochemical plants often include thousands of variables. The efficiency of algorithm used to build SDG model for these systems is important.13,14 To test the efficiency of the proposed algorithm, another example is illustrated below. In this example, a compressor unit system was used to test the efficiency of the algorithm. As shown in Figure 12, this compressor unit system consists of one centrifugal compressor, one supercharger, one steam turbine and other accessory subsystems. There are 90 main variables are used in system monitoring and control. Main variables of compressor unit system are listed in Table 1. The other variables were not listed due to the limitation of paper length.15,16 Figure 12.
Compressor unit system.
Table 1.
Main variables of compressor unit system.
Variable Function Variable Function
PI7601 Inflow air pressure ZI7600 Guide vane opening
PI76010 Section I inflow air pressure TI7605 Section I inflow air temperature
PI76011 Section I expulsion air pressure TI7608 Section I expulsion air temperature A
TI7606 Section I expulsion air temperature B PI76012 Section II inflow air pressure
TI7609 Section II inflow air temperature PI76013 Section II expulsion air pressure
TI7612 Section II expulsion air temperature A TI7610 Section II expulsion air temperature B
PI76014 Section III inflow air pressure TI7613 Section III inflow air temperature
TI7616 Section III expulsion air temperature TI7614 Section III expulsion air pressure B
PI76015 Section III expulsion air pressure A PI7602 Compressor expulsion air pressure
TI7602 Compressor expulsion air temperature FI7601 Compressor expulsion air flow rate
SI7630 Spindle speed of compressor BV7600 Release valve opening

This compressor unit system contains more than 80 algebraic and differential equations which cannot be illustrated in detail for the sake of secrecy. In our project, the program which has been used in enterprise takes Browser–Server mode. The algorithm proposed in this article is embedded into the code of the page, which are called ‘beans’. The equations are input on the input page and stored in database. The cause–effect relation between variables can then be calculated and the SDG models are constructed and illustrated to users automatically in the output page, as shown in Figure 13. The silverlight technology in web programming significantly facilitated the illustration of SDG in web pages. Figure 13.
SDG modelling and illustration page of the project.

The algebraic and differential equations of compressor unit system were input on the equation input page and stored in the database. These equations can also be input into the database in batches on the table management interface. After determining exogenous variables under assistance provided by program, the algorithm run at backstage and give the automatically constructed SDG model, as shown in Figure 14. Figure 14.
SDG model of compressor unit system constructed by program.

sec.title: Comparison analysis
sec.p:
For comparison, the algorithm of Maurya et al.7 was also programmed and added into our project. The equation input interface and SDG construction and illustration page share those already developed in our project. The beans behind the page which contain core algorithm of cause–effect analysis are different. The development and test environment configurations are listed in Table 2. Table 2.
Development and test environment configurations.
Sever Browser
CPU Pentium Dual Core 2.0 GHz CPU Pentium Dual Core 1.6 GHz
RAM 2 G RAM 1 G
HDD 320 G HDD 120 G
Network 10 Mbps Ethernet/Internet Network 10 Mbps Ethernet/Internet
OS Microsoft Windows Server 2003 SP1 OS Microsoft Windows XP SP3
DB Oracle 10 g Browser Internet Explorer 7
Development Environment Microsoft Visual Studio 2008

The SDG model of the compressor unit system eventually constructed are the same to that constructed by our method, but the efficiency is different, as shown in Table 3. Table 3.
Program performance test.
Test item The proposed algorithm Algorithm of Maurya
Average memory consumption (k) 223,408 305,358
Run time of program (ms) 322,540 1,335,826

The most likely reason that leads to the difference of the program performance is not the algorithm structure, but the data storage structure. The algorithm proposed in this article needs only one table to store system equations by two fields. The iteration of variables between different equations is executed in the code by character operation. This procedure needs less data call from the database. The algorithm of Maurya et al.7 takes advantage of graph. So, it needs code and table to store adjacency matrix of system variables graph. The construction and manipulation of system variables graph frequently reads and writes the adjacency table. The perfect matching identification also needs additional algorithm to execute and separate table to store the relation between equations and variables.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: To overcome the disadvantages of existing SDG modelling methods which often introduce false causality, a new SDG modelling method based on causal dependence identification is proposed. Simon and Iwasaki have put forward the concept of causal ordering analysis. Based on their work, causal dependence identification process was investigated in detail and resulted in an algorithm that can identify causal dependence of system variables through catching the causal dependence transferring process. SCCs identification is another problem of SDG modelling. From detailed investigation, the conclusion was made that SCCs are those self-contained subsystems containing at least two variables. SCCs of self-contained system can be identified through distinguishing system equations solvability. On this basis, an improved algorithm which can perform causal dependence identification for system with SCCs was proposed. SDG modelling method for mixed process system based on causal dependence identification was summarized at last. Two case studies of SDG modelling based on the proposed method were illustrated. From the comparison results of the first case study of a series connected liquid storage system, it can be seen that the proposed method can identify causal dependence between system variables accurately and eliminate false causality obtained by existing SDG modelling method. Focusing on the efficiency of the algorithm of the proposed method, the second case study investigated the SDG modelling of a compressor unit system with nearly one hundred variables. The comparison result shows that the proposed method is less time-intensive with less resource consumption and can be effectively performed by computer. It is very important for SDG modelling of large-scale process systems.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This work was supported by the National High Technology Research and Development Program (Project 2007AA04Z432) and the National Nature Science Foundation of China (Project 61104025).

ack.p: We gratefully acknowledge the valuable cooperation of Wei-he Coal Chemical Group in accomplishing the research project.
